content.webTitle: Eddie Jones warns of All Blacks' Big Bad Wolf while wary of Ireland backlash

fields.headline: Eddie Jones warns of All Blacks' Big Bad Wolf while wary of Ireland backlash
fields.bodyText: Eddie Jones has stoked the rivalry between England and New Zealand by comparing his All Black counterpart, Steve Hansen, to the cunning Big Bad Wolf in Little Red Riding Hood and warning his players not to be seduced by the warm words of praise from the southern hemisphere over the weekend. New Zealand’s head coach was complimentary about England following their 61-21 win against Scotland, suggesting they looked fitter and more motivated than they had done previously. Jones, however, suspects Hansen of trying to lull his squad – and, potentially, the British & Irish Lions – into a false sense of security. “It’s a bit like Little Red Riding Hood and the Big Bad Wolf when the wolf comes dressed up as the grandmother,” Jones said. “When an All Black coach is complimenting you, you always have to be careful.” England are not due to face New Zealand for another 18 months but will end the Six Nations ranked second behind the All Blacks regardless of whether they complete a grand slam in Dublin on Saturday. Jones repeatedly talks about England’s desire to knock the world champions off their lofty perch but does not want his players getting ahead of themselves. “We don’t have to worry about [New Zealand] because we are not playing them,” he said. “All we have to do is worry about playing against Ireland.” The mental image of Hansen clad in wolf’s clothing will not be easy to shift, another bonus from Jones’s point of view. He will not have forgotten the lampooning of himself and Australia’s Michael Chieka as clowns by Australian and New Zealand publications last year but, more pertinently, he is determined to ensure England develop a harder edge before the 2019 World Cup. That goal was the subject of a “cleansing meeting” in Oxford after the Italy game when the squad openly discussed how to deal with their lengthening unbeaten record. “We just felt we needed to reset our minds a little bit,” Jones said. “You can feel within the team there’s a different intensity about the way we do things. I thought we were always going to play well against Scotland – and I think we’ll play better this week. “What we said – and we had a great discussion – is that we have to acknowledge we’ve been successful and it’s now about how much we want to be great. How many opportunities in your life do you get to beat Ireland in Ireland to win back-to-back grand slams? It’s almost a childhood dream as a rugby player.” Part of the process, Jones said, is to treat this week’s concluding game like a World Cup final, even though England are already Six Nations champions. “For us everything’s about the World Cup. If you look at where we are now, we’ve been together approximately eight weeks. You’re together eight or nine weeks to get to a World Cup final. When you get to the World Cup final, no one’s 100%. Everyone’s carrying injuries. “It’s the team that prepares with the mind-set that nothing’s going to stop them being at their best that wins the World Cup. You want to develop a winning mentality. It’s a great dress rehearsal for us for the World Cup. All these milestones along the way are nice but they’re not things that we cherish. It’s what we do in the future that matters.” Jones is also cautioning his players against assuming Ireland are vulnerable after losing to Wales. He does not know the Ireland head coach, Joe Schmidt, well but believes the home team will be “grossly disappointed” by their performance in Cardiff. “Ireland will come with a lot of emotion. Disappointment builds aggression,” said Jones. “We’ve seen how Wales came back after losing to Scotland so we expect Ireland to be like that. We have to be more aggressive, more emotional in the right way, more committed as well as smart and skilful.” Nor will England’s players waste time worrying about potential Lions’ showdowns with their Ireland opposite numbers. “Our desire is to be the best team in the world so we don’t need any external motivation,” Jones said. “We don’t talk about the Lions. All we’re worried about is playing well this week. The players realise they have a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity here. History shows that winning back-to-back grand slams happens once in every 27 years. None of these players is going to be playing in 27 years’ time.” The England management believe Elliot Daly will be fit to feature against Ireland after breaking his nose and suffering blurred vision against Scotland. The Wasps back is going through the necessary return-to-play protocols which will prevent him from training fully until later in the week.
